awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Creating and Studying Plasma Structures for Extreme Optics
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this effort is to develop methods to compress and manipulate laser pulses to reach unprecedented intensities. Such new capability will enable access to new regimes of high-energy density science, including studies of materials under extreme conditions that exist in stars and planetary interiors.  The constraints on laser intensity arise because conventional optical components are damaged or destroyed when exposed to high intensity lasers. This research will investigate how these limits can be overcome when  conventional optical elements are replaced with plasma structures.  At a fundamental level, the project investigates the control of nonlinear systems with large numbers of interacting components as a theme that runs through many branches of physics and is one of the greatest challenges in modern science.  This research is also expected to have a significant impact on optical science by allowing for new regimes of optical manipulation of intense laser pulses and may lead to new ideas for inertial fusion and plasma-based ion accelerators. 

Unlike conventional structures, where an electric field triggers changes in structure behavior, plasma can be sculpted using light manipulation techniques to create novel, robust, optical elements on nanosecond timescales. Within this broad area of inquiry, the research supported by this award will focus on generating Bragg reflectors by manipulating ion acoustic waves. Theoretical research will examine structure dynamics and their utility for intense pulse compression. Such structures may be stationary or moving. The United States-Israel Binational Science Foundation will support closely coupled collaborative experimental and theoretical research on the autoresonant excitation of large amplitude ion acoustic waves that serve as the backbone of the proposed structures. Ideas that have been theoretically studied and experimentally tested on a small scale at the Hebrew University laboratory may be investigated on a larger experimental set-up at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. This wave excitation study will involve state-of-the art research on the control of nonlinear collective systems within the context of both multi-dimensional and multi-wave effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ultra-intense lasers are a tool of discovery for high-energy density physics, advanced plasma-based accelerators, and inertial confinement fusion. Manipulations such as focusing or steering of such intense pulses, cannot be achieved with conventional optics. The lasers are powerful enough to destroy the optical elements being used to control them. Plasma, on the other hand, has a breakdown threshold that is much higher than that of a conventional (i.e., solid) optical element. This has led to much research in the field of plasma photonics. There are significant challenges to using plasmas as optical elements. The plasma density must be properly controlled to possess the requisite optical properties. Gratings, for example, require the imposition of a periodic structure in plasma density.  The structure must have sufficient variation in plasma density and physical extent if it is to, for example, deflect an incident, intense, laser pulse. 

The goal of this project was to develop greater understanding of how to create structures for plasma photonics.  Three papers summarize our results:

1. M. R. Edwards et al., Holographic plasma lenses, Phys. Rev. Lett. 128, 065003 (2022). Our theory and simulation research was in support of an experiment by Prof. Matthew Edwards, Stanford University. The development of a new holographic plasma lens based on ionization of a gas via the peak fields in beat waves may result in new capabilities to focus intense pulses . This was emphasized in the Physics Synopsis (https://physics.aps.org/articles/v15/s16) write-up that appeared in the APS Physics Magazine, which highlights the best Physical Review (all journals) papers each week in a newsletter and online. 

2. V. R. Munirov et al., Autoresonant excitation of space-time quasicrystals in plasma, Phys. Rev. Research 4, 023150 (2022). This paper studies a new variant of the ion acoustic plasma wave that has two phases. Two-phase waves are of interest to the nonlinear PDE community while the structures themselves should be of interest to those working in plasma photonics.  This aspect of the research was one reason APS Physics Magazine highlighted this research. (https://physics.aps.org/articles/v15/s71). The attached figure shows the space-time variation of the plasma density in a two-phase nonlinear ion acoustic wave. The color coding shows the density variation, the vertical axis is (a normalized) spatial direction (x) and a normalized time is along the horizontal axis.

3. V. R. Munirov et al., Multiphase nonlinear electron plasma waves, Phys. Rev. E 106, 055201 (2022). This paper is similar to #2 above, except that it considers nonlinear electron wave-like structures which may have applications to plasma photonics for short-pulse intense lasers. It also contains a first attempt to address the question of possible parameters for an experimental test of both the electron and ion wave variations of a two-phase nonlinear excitation.
